title: Dow edges higher at midday, stocks shake off early weakness as investors parse inflation data
text:
* The S&P 500 SPX rose 11 points, or 0.3%, to 3,974.

* The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA gained 41 points, or 0.1%, at 33,823.

* The Nasdaq Composite COMP rose 47 points, or 0.4%, to 11,129.

All three major U.S. stock indexes were on track to finish the week deeply in the red. For the year, the S&P 500 was down more than 16%, the Dow down off 7% and the Nasdaq Composite 29% lower.

What's driving markets

Equities have been locked in choppy trade, with a mix of defensive and cyclical sectors outperforming once again, as investors digested a fresh round of economic data to help gauge the path of inflation.

Particular attention was paid to the monthly U.S. producer price index figures, which showed wholesale prices rose 0.3% in November, compared with expectations for a 0.2% gain from economists polled by The Wall Street Journal. The pace of producer-price growth for October and September was also revised higher.

The upshot is that while the pace of price increases over the prior 12 months slowed from the prior month, the extent of the pullback didn't satisfy investors' hopes for a substantial easing, according to Peter Boockvar, chief investment officer of Bleakley Financial. Core producer prices advanced 0.4% in November, compared with expectations for a 0.2% gain.

"I'm amazed how many think that we're just going to quickly go back to a pre-COVID environment with inflation, and I just don't see it, especially if one listens directly to what companies are saying," Boockvar said.

In other economic data, the University of Michigangauge of consumer sentimentrose to a preliminary December reading of 59.1 from 56.8 in November. But market strategists said investors remain focused on next week's November consumer-price index to gain a fuller view on inflation.

"Onward to the CPI number next week, we need to see what happens there," said John Stoltzfus, chief investment strategist at Oppenheimer.

Battered stocks in the technology-heavy communications services sector were leading the S&P 500 higher on Friday.

"Growth is beginning to regain some favor on some days," Stoltzfus said. "That's a healthy sign in our view."

Stocks in focus

* Netflix Inc. NFLXshares saw a modest pop on Friday after an analyst upgrade.

* Shares of Walt Disney Company DISwere the best-performers on the Dow as the company made its debut its ad-supported streaming tier.

* Microsoft Corp. MSFT shares were in focus after the company announced in a Friday morning blog post that it had acquired Lumenisity Limited, which makes hollow core fiber (HCF) solutions, as its battle with the FTC over the Activision Blizzard Inc. ATVIdeal deepens.
